We are writing to inform you of an upcoming change with Travel Compass Magazine, where we pride ourselves on providing fresh and accurate information about various travel destinations. Our dedication to reliable and up-to-date content sets us apart in the travel magazine industry. However, due to rising production and distribution costs, we need to increase our subscription fees. Sincerely, Travel Compass Magazine

annotations.html: Our group behaviour may be defined by our different personalities, but much of the human instinct is towards uniformity. Most of us are basically driven by the desire to fit in, and win acceptance from our peers. Although we fulfil different roles in social situations, this is largely done unconsciously, and we don't understand and harness these dynamics in a helpful way. What's more, our urge to belong risks being counterproductive, when it is actually our differences that define us and underpin effective communication and cooperation. Rather than denying or masking our true personality, we should embrace and harness it. If you're a listener, then make the most of being someone with high levels of empathy; or if you're one of the world's kinases, then your ability to make people laugh is probably your superpower. We would work better as humans-in both social and professional contexts-if we allowed ourselves to be ourselves, and were more accepting of other people doing the same.

annotations.html: 다음 글의 주제로 가장 적절한 것은?
annotations.text: 다음 글의 주제로 가장 적절한 것은?

annotations.html: The books one most remembers deliver their quarry so wonderfully that those (fictional) lives actually exist in people's minds alongside the "real" people one knows. Oedipus, Hamlet, Jane Eyre, Gatsby-among many others-occupy a good bit of human real estate, and some have claimed that we may know them better, more fully, than we know the "actual" people we know. Further: one actually sees the arc of those fictional lives: Oedipus's transition from proud King back to cast-out infant and closing as blind exile; Jane Eyre's arc from unloved and abused child to wealthy, married woman. This, we say, is the work of plot. But consider the true magic here: how all these transformations (which can take weeks, months, years, even a lifetime to happen, which therefore escape our vision, our knowing) are compressed, contained, or delivered in the scope of a few hundred pages, requiring mere hours to access, to process. We enter the bookstore, see all the books arrayed there, and think: so many books, so little time; but the truth goes other way: books do not take time, they give time.

annotations.html: Some people say that science just is, that it is merely a collection of facts and measurements that exist outside of the realm of emotion and caring. But I disagree. Of the millions (perhaps infinity) of possible facts about the world we memorize, document, and pass on to others, we select those that we think are important, and this is an emotional judgment. We are motivated to care about some and not others, and emotion and motivation are two sides of the same neurochemical coin. It is true that the mere fact that 2+2=4, or that hydrogen is the lightest element we know of, is without emotional content. But the fact that we know these things, have gone to the trouble to learn them, reflects interests, priorities, motivation - in short, reflects emotion. Scientists are motivated by intense curiosity and a desire to interpret and represent reality in terms of higher truths - to take collections of observations and formulate them into a coherent whole that we call a theory.

annotations.html: True, human decision-making is full of biases and inconsistencies, but our inconsistencies are relatively predictable. We know how to account for them. And there are limits to how nonsensical an intelligent, balanced person's 'wrong' decision will be, due to the vague, currently uncomputable concept we call 'common sense'. This is not necessarily the case with Al . When Al is 'wrong', it can be spectacularly wrong, with more unpredictable outcomes. Simple algorithms should be extremely predictable, but can make bizarre decisions in 'unusual' circumstances. A trivial example: in 2011, two very basic pricing algorithms - one programmed to sell a book a shade cheaper than its nearest competitor, the other to sell a book at a considerably higher price than its competitors - kept automatically pushing each other's prices up, to the point where a textbook was being sold on amazon for $23 million. Less trivially, unusual circumstances (concerns over European debt crisis leading to unusual algorithmic stock sales), and a cascade of unexpected interactions between high-frequency trading algorithms played a key role in wiping a trillion dollars off the US stock market during the 2010 Flash Crash.

annotations.html: Jean Macnamara (1899-1968), an Australian medical scientist, was born into a family that prized hard work and education. She studied medicine at the University of Melbourne, graduating in 1922, and the following year, she was appointed resident medical officer at the Royal Children's Hospital, where she specialized in polio care. In 1931, in collaboration with future Nobel Prize winner Macfarlane Burnet, she discovered that there was more than one type of the polio virus and their finding was a crucial step toward the eventual development of the polio vaccine by Jonas Salk in 1955. Macnamara also developed new methods of treatments and rehabilitation for disabled patients. Her remarkable ability to inspire confidence in her patients, mostly children, filled her clinics with families prepared to wait hours for her attention. She married a fellow physician, Joseph Connor, in 1934 and had two daughters. Macnamara passed away in 1968 due to heart disease, and her funeral was attended by many of her former patients.

annotations.html: According to the traditional mainstream view, science is a collection of certified truths. For Aristotle, the premises of scientific syllogisms are necessary truths. The medieval conception of science was static: scientia is the possession and contemplation of knowledge, and its method is needed to organize the already established truths for the purpose of teaching. However, after the Scientific Revolution in the early seventeenth century, Francis Bacon and René Descartes advocated the dynamic view that the aim of science is to find new truths by inquiry. After this shift in the aims of science, it became relevant to raise the conceptual problem about scientific progress: what is meant by progress in science? Both the empiricist Bacon and the rationalist Descartes adhered to the requirement that scientific knowledge is completely certain to be true-at least after the employment of right inductive or deductive methods-and hence they answered the conceptual problem by asserting that scientific progress is the accumulation of knowledge.

annotations.html: Many of us have seen the phenomenon of adults in online social groups who shut down or even "unfriend" those who bring up controversial topics, probably because they do not want to experience strong negative emotions in their social experiences. The same can happen if you are researching a science topic online. These strong emotions can lead to what psychologists call "foreclosure," shutting down the critical thinking process prematurely before one has the information needed to make an evidence-based decision. For example, many individuals are avoiding specific foods based more on fads than on true medical risk factors. A small percentage of people cannot tolerate gluten, yet gluten-free products are broadly popular. Some individuals may be missing out on easy ways to get key nutrients by avoiding foods that are fine for them. Recognizing how negative emotions and attitudes may be leading to rejection of scientific information without full evaluation is a first step. Be open to new ideas, and be sure to evaluate them critically.

annotations.html: What is time? Here is a concept we all think we understand, and one that physics requires. Yet both ordinary folk and physicists would be hard-pressed to tell us what exactly time is. Notice that to define time in terms of hours, minutes, and seconds is to mistake the units of time for what they measure. It would be like defining space in terms of meters or yards. Space is measured with equal accuracy in meters or yards. But suppose we ask which is the correct way of measuring space? The answer of course is that there is no uniquely correct set of units for measuring space; yards and meters do equally well. By the same token, neither can be said to "define" or constitute space. The same goes for time. Seconds, centuries, millennia are just different amounts of the same "thing." And it's that thing, time, which comes in different amounts that we want a definition of. We could say that time is duration, but then duration is just the passage of time. Our definition would presuppose the very notion we set out to define.

annotations.html: What is time? Here is a ① concept we all think we understand, and one that physics requires. Notice that to ② define time in terms of hours, minutes, and seconds is to mistake the units of time for what they ③ measure. It would be like defining space in terms of meters or yards. Space is measured with equal accuracy in meters or yards. But suppose we ask which is the correct way of measuring space? The answer of course is that there is no uniquely correct set of units for measuring space; yards and meters do equally well. By the same token, neither can be said to "define" or constitute space. annotations.html: It's worth noting that a writer can't manifest all qualities to all people at all times. With great solemnity like Tolstoy's, you rarely get lightheartedness humor (although he does enjoy mocking the weaknesses of some of his minor characters). A chatty author―one who is enthusiastic about lots of details and commentary―can't also be a strong, silent Hemingway type. The very qualities that we identify as the reasons we like an author's voice may be the identical reasons why other readers dislike the voice. One reader finds the work brilliant, another show-offy. One reader's philosophically deep is another's ponderous. One reader's funny is another reader's trivial. Even a writer's rich imagery, her flights of poetry, may cause some readers to warn, "I don't care how dawn breaks on yonder sky. Get on with it!" In evaluating fiction, we don't want to ask whether it's what we want for dinner, but whether the food is properly prepared and presented―not whether we approve of the voice, but whether the writer has achieved the desired effect well and consistently.

annotations.html: The earliest document that might be considered a student record was an annual "child census." These censuses were often required by states as they developed their early public school systems and were used for the purpose of assessing taxes, and, later, determining the denominator for school attendance rates. These were records of children who should be students, but they weren't student records - they didn't record individual attendance or achievement. The need for individual records changed, however, once states passed compulsory school laws that required all children of a certain age to attend. Now schools were increasingly expected to maintain common sets of records that allowed information to be transferred from school to school in order to keep track of students and verify that families were complying with school laws. In addition to being good for record-keeping, the practice was intended to thwart an excuse common among youth stopped by truant officers: they weren't absent, they were simply crossing town to the school where they were enrolled. A quick check of a school's records could determine the truth of the claim - and whether the student's family would be issued a warning or worse.

annotations.html: Social media has become an important means of large-scale information sharing and communication in all occupations, including marketing, journalism, public relations, and more. This change in consumption behaviors is due to some novel features such as mobility, being free, and interactiveness. However, the low cost, easy access, and rapid distribution of information of social media draw a large audience and enable the wide spread of fake news, i.e., news with intentionally false information. For instance, in 2016, millions of people read and "liked" fake news stories proclaiming that Pope Francis had supported a specific candidate for U.S. president. When the Pakistani defense minister mistakenly believed a fake news story, he almost started a war with a neighboring country. These examples clearly demonstrate that fake news stories are problematic not only for the credibility of online journalism, but also due to their adverse real-world consequences, resulting in violence or influencing election results. Therefore, it becomes increasingly important for policy makers to regulate and discourage the creation of fake news, for online businesses to detect and prevent fake news, and for citizens to protect themselves from fake news.

annotations.html: Social media has become an important means of large-scale information sharing and communication in all occupations, including marketing, journalism, public relations, and more. This change in consumption behaviors is due to some novel features such as mobility, being free, and interactiveness. However, the low cost, easy access, and rapid distribution of information of social media draw a large audience and enable the wide spread of fake news, i.e., news with intentionally false information. For instance, in 2016, millions of people read and "liked" fake news stories proclaiming that Pope Francis had supported a specific candidate for U.S. president. When the Pakistani defense minister mistakenly believed a fake news story, he almost started a war with a neighboring country. _______________ Therefore, it becomes increasingly important for policy makers to regulate and discourage the creation of fake news, for online businesses to detect and prevent fake news, and for citizens to protect themselves from fake news.

annotations.html: The successful functioning of people and societies requires a successful perception and cognition of the circumstances in the physical and social environment in which we live. To be successful in everyday life, though, as individuals, we need not know everything. As Tuan, the father of humanistic geography, put it, the geographical "knowledge we have as individuals and as members of a particular society remains very limited, selective, and biased." Despite imperfect geographical information and knowledge and limited abilities to think geographically we - as individuals and societies - have to cope with everyday or long-term challenges. To do so, we need both geographical knowledge and the abilities to act effectively in new situations. This knowledge is accumulated and strengthened through formal and informal education as well as through personal or collectively shared experiences. This justifies the importance of learning just-in-case about previously unknown geographies, like through geography lessons in schools, reading literature or following the media news.

annotations.html: One of the brain's specialized mental organs is a primitive number processor that prefigures, without quite matching it, the arithmetic that is taught in our schools. ① Improbable as it may seem, numerous animal species that we consider stupid or vicious, such as rats and pigeons, ② are actually quite gifted at calculation. They can represent quantities mentally and transform them according to some of the rules of arithmetic. The scientists who have studied these abilities believe that animals possess a mental module, traditionally called the "accumulator," ③ that can hold a register of various quantities. Rats exploit this mental accumulator to distinguish series of two, three, or four sounds, or ④ to compute approximate additions of two quantities. The accumulator mechanism opens up a new dimension of sensory perception through which the cardinal of a set of objects can be perceived just as ⑤ easy as their color, shape, or position. This "number sense" provides animals and humans alike with a direct intuition of what numbers mean.

The scientists who have studied these abilities believe that animals possess a mental module, traditionally called the "accumulator," that can hold a register of various quantities. Rats exploit this mental accumulator to distinguish series of two, three, or four sounds, or to compute approximate additions of two quantities. The accumulator mechanism opens up a new dimension of sensory perception through which the cardinal of a set of objects can be perceived just as easily as their color, shape, or position. This "number sense" provides animals and humans alike with a direct intuition of what numbers mean.

④ A mental module called the accumulator makes cardinal recognition possible.
⑤ Scientists believe animals possess a mental system to store and manipulate quantities.

annotations.html: You've probably noticed that as a TV or radio program yields to a commercial, the speech rate often increases. The reason for this can be purely practical, to squeeze in as much information as possible into a pricey 30-second commercial slot. Sometimes, when the taped commercial runs slightly over the allotted time, it's compressed to fit in, so it runs faster than actual life. Researchers began to notice that time-compressed commercials could actually be more effective than the same commercial run at normal speed. When they took a closer look they found that surprisingly, people use less brainpower, not more, in listening to time-compressed ads. Since thinking takes more time than reacting, it may be that people just gave up on it when the speech ran faster than cognition. In that case, we'd expect to see signs that people were thinking superficially when they heard time-compressed ads. Sure enough, ads that sounded extremely fast led to people relying less on the strength of its arguments, and more on a general impression of how credible the announcer seemed.

annotations.html: Creativity, like ethics, beauty, decision-making, or the ability to think or reason, is not located anywhere in the brain. To create means having the ability to get excited and think, learn, remember, imagine, and all these are brain functions ① whose processing is distributed in areas, neural systems, and specific networks ② functioning within codes of time, not space. Creativity is an important ingredient in any artistic activity. It is the capacity to do new things, therefore, ③ that enables the artist to capture on canvas, wood, rock, or holograms feelings, abstracts, and ideals. It has been ④ speculated that the artistic creativity may emerge from that clash between the abstractions created by the brain, with its emotional component, unique and personal, and the concrete sensory objects of the world from which precisely those same abstractions have been constructed. Think of this as something like an unconscious dissatisfaction caused by a mismatch between mental objects and real sensory objects, between ideas of the objects created by the brain and the real objects themselves, something like a divorce between the "tree" the artist sees, which is "real," and the "tree" that the artist constructs unconsciously on the screen of his mind. From that conflict agreement, an emotional reaction arises, leading to that dissatisfaction (frustration). It could be precisely this frustration that acts as the starter of the creative process. The creative act would then stand as the need of the artist to find a personal satisfaction through his work of art, with this work no longer ⑤ reflected the "objective reality" but his "mental reality."

annotations.html: Puz wakes me up with her movements. I try to pat her, but my hand in empty air truly wakes me up. Puz is my eleven-year-old golden retriever, retired search-and-rescue dog, and I was her partner in finding missing persons. When she retired, I adopted her. We take a nap together, but today, something gets her up. I follow her to the front yard and see a young woman running toward us. Now I understand what woke her up. The woman's expression is panicked. "My dog," she says. "My dog is gone." She struggles to catch her breath. "A lady next to my house... says you... your dog... says she can..." She looks at me and Puz blankly, like she doesn't know what to ask for. "My dog... he is old and his heart is bad," she says. "We'll help," I say. As I put the leash on Puz, she seems ready for the task ahead. But I wonder. Puz was trained to find people, not animals. Can she find a missing pet? I worry that she might not. "His name is Odie," the young woman tells us about her dog as we jog back to her house. She says while she was in the kitchen, someone else in the house was going in and out through the front door. "Maybe the door screen didn't close tightly and that's how the dog got out," she adds. When we arrive at her house, she gestures for us to enter. Moving quickly, Puz and I search the house. Puz sniffs around to track Odie down. She stops and looks at me as if to say, "No sign of the little dog here." Puz leads us to a back door, signaling me to go out. "There is no way he could have gone out this way," the young woman says. I ask her to stay inside not to distract Puz. My golden retriever stretches toward some tall bushes, and from beneath them, a small black dog slides toward her, whimpering and dragging his legs. I pick up Odie and carry him back inside. The young woman bursts into tears, shouting his name. She thanks us a million times. Puz seems satisfied and looks at me as if to say, "Can we go back to our nap now?"

We take a nap together, but today, something gets her up. I follow her to the front yard and see a young woman running toward us. Now I understand what woke her up. The woman's expression is panicked. "My dog," she says. "My dog is gone." She struggles to catch her breath. "A lady next to my house... says you... your dog... says she can..." She looks at me and Puz blankly, like she doesn't know what to ask for. "My dog... he is old and his heart is bad," she says. "We'll help," I say. As I put the leash on Puz, she seems ready for the task ahead. But I wonder. _______________. "His name is Odie," the young woman tells us about her dog as we jog back to her house. She says while she was in the kitchen, someone else in the house was going in and out through the front door. "Maybe the door screen didn't close tightly and that's how the dog got out," she adds. When we arrive at her house, she gestures for us to enter. Moving quickly, Puz and I search the house. Puz sniffs around to track Odie down. She stops and looks at me as if to say, "No sign of the little dog here." Puz leads us to a back door, signaling me to go out. "There is no way he could have gone out this way," the young woman says. I ask her to stay inside not to distract Puz. My golden retriever stretches toward some tall bushes, and from beneath them, a small black dog slides toward her, whimpering and dragging his legs. I pick up Odie and carry him back inside. The young woman bursts into tears, shouting his name. She thanks us a million times. Puz seems satisfied and looks at me as if to say, "Can we go back to our nap now?"

annotations.html:
① I felt calm knowing Puz had done this kind of search many times.
② I knew this would be easier than any rescue we'd done before.
③ I remembered training her specifically to find small lost pets.
④ I had no doubt she would find the lost dog quickly and safely.
⑤ I was unsure whether she could apply her skills to a different task.

113) 정답: (3)
-- 보기해석:
(1) 개인과 사회 모두 제한된 지식을 가지고 지리적 문제에 대처해야 한다.
(2) 지리 지식은 교육과 삶의 경험을 통해 형성될 수 있다.
(3) 성공적인 삶을 살기 위해 지리에 대해 모든 것을 아는 것이 필요하다.
(4) 미디어, 문학, 학교는 지리적 학습의 수단으로 언급된다.
(5) 우리의 지리적 지식은 선택적이고 편향된 관점에 의해 형성되고 제한된다.
-- 해설: 글에서는 모든 것을 알 필요는 없다고 하며, 오히 려 제한된 지식으로도 문제에 대처할 수 있다고 설명한 다. (3)번은 이 점에서 본문과 어긋난다.
114) 정답: (1)
-- 보기해석:
(1) 도전과제를 극복하려면 지식과 실질적인 지리적 능력이 모두 필요하다.
(2) 일상 적응은 사실보다는 감정에 더 크게 의존한다.
(3) 추상적인 지리 이론만으로도 일상 행동을 이끌기에 충분 하다.
(4) 새로운 상황은 사전 지리학 지식 없이 대응하는 것이 가 장 좋다.
(5) 지리 교육은 잘 알려진 환경에만 초점을 맞춰야 한다.
-- 해설: 빈칸 앞뒤 문장은 개인과 사회가 지리적 지식과 행 동 능력을 통해 새로운 상황에 대처해야 함을 강조한다. (1)은 이를 간결하고 정확하게 반영하는 선택지이며, 나 머지 보기들은 본문의 핵심 취지를 왜곡하거나 축소시 킨 주장이다.
115) 정답: (3)

해설: (ㄷ) 문장은 앞에서 강조한 지리 지식의 필요성과 모순 되며, 지리보다 경제 전략에 집중해야 한다는 내용은 문 맥에서 벗어난 주장이다. 주제 흐름과 일치하지 않는다.
116) 정답: (2)

해설: 지문은 우리가 갖는 지리 지식이 **매우 제한적 (limited)**이며 선택적이고 편향되어 있다는 현실을 강 조하고 있음. 이를 **unlimited(무제한의)**라고 바꾸면 저자의 핵심 주장을 정면으로 부정하는 표현이 되어 부 적절함.

해설:
-- <as+ 형용사/부사 원급+ as> 구문으로 동사구 "can be perceived"를 수식하므로 부사가 적절함.
118) 정답: (2)
-- 보기해석
(1) (A) 표시기
(B) 형태 기억
(2) (A) 축적기
(B) 수 감각
(3) (A) 조율기
(B) 리듬 감지기
(4) (A) 암기장치
(B) 본능 단서
(5) (A) 번역기
(B) 시각 체계
-- 요약해석: 동물들조차도 (A)축적기(accumulator)라는 정신 적 장치를 사용하여 수량을 처리하며, 이는 인간과 유사 하게 기본적인 산술 지각을 가능케 하는 (B)수 감각 (number sense)을 제공한다.
119) 정답: (2)

-- 보기해석:
(1) 일부 동물은 그들의 누산기를 사용하여 다양한 소리를 구별하거나 양을 결합한다.
(2) 쥐와 비둘기는 산술을 정확히 수행하는 능력을 보여주었 다.
(3) 수 감각은 동물들이 형태나 색깔처럼 수량을 직관적으로 이해하게 해준다.
(4) 누산기라 불리는 정신 모듈은 기수 인식을 가능하게 한 다.
(5) 과학자들은 동물들이 수량을 저장하고 조작할 수 있는 정신 체계를 갖고 있다고 믿는다.
-- 해설: 지문에서는 동물들이 수량을 '근사적으로' 더한다고 언급하고 있어 정확한 산술을 한다는 표현은 부적절하 다. (2)번이 지문과 불일치한다.
120) 정답: (2)
-- 보기해석:
(1) 동물은 숫자를 인간의 훈련과 조건화로만 배운다.
(2) 이 직관적인 숫자 능력은 동물과 인간 모두가 숫자의 의 미를 파악할 수 있게 한다.
(3) 정신적 누산기는 시각적 사물을 셀 때만 작동한다.
(4) 동물의 수 처리 능력은 인간의 뇌 작용과는 관련이 없 다.
(5) 동물의 산술 능력은 항상 수학의 기호적 이해로 이어진 다.
-- 해설: 빈칸 앞 문장은 동물들이 'accumulator'를 통해 수 량을 인식하고 처리할 수 있음을 보여준다. (2)는 이 능 력이 인간과 동물 모두에게 숫자에 대한 직관을 제공한 다는 내용을 정확히 요약하고 있어 가장 적절하다. 다른 선택지들은 본문 내용과 상반되거나 과도한 해석을 담 고 있다.

123) 정답: (1)

--(A) 문장이 이러한 동물들이 수량을 마음속으로 표현하고 계산 규칙에 따라 조작할 수 있다는 사실을 이어서 설 명합니다.

② 알고리즘은 다른 모든 원칙보다 논리성과 효율성을 우선시하도록 설계된다.
③ AI는 특히 압박이 큰 금융 환경에서 심각한 실수를 거의 하지 않는다.
④ 스마트 기술은 예측 불가능한 상황에서 항상 인간보다 더 나은 성과를 낸다.
⑤ AI의 오류는 예기치 않게 심각할 수 있으며, 인간의 불일치보다 훨씬 큰 결과를 낳는다.
-- 해설: 빈칸 앞에서는 인간의 불일치가 어느 정도 예측 가능하지만, AI의 오류는 심각하고 예측 불가능할 수 있음을 강조하고 있다. 이 문맥에 가장 잘 들어맞는 것은 AI 의 오류가 인간보다 훨씬 심각하다는 내용이다.

② 그녀는 소아마비 바이러스 유형을 규명하기 위해 맥팔레인 버넷과 협업했다.

annotations.html:
-- 보기해석:
① 학생 등록을 관리하고 법적 준수를 보장하기 위해 학교들은 통일된 기록을 유지하기 시작했다.
② 학생들의 효율적인 전학을 돕기 위해 학교들은 지역 지도를 보관하기 시작했다.
③ 일일 출석 체크를 빠르게 하기 위해 학교들은 출석 키오스크를 설치하기 시작했다.
④ 학생들의 교내 이동을 추적하기 위해 학교들은 신분증을 발급하기 시작했다.
⑤ 새로운 등록 시스템에 맞추기 위해 학교들은 식단표를 갱신하기 시작했다.
-- 해설: 정답인 ①은 학생 추적 및 법적 준수를 위한 기록 유지라는 내용과 일치하며, 전체 문맥과도 자연스럽게 연결된다. 다른 선택지는 그럴듯하지만 학생 기록 유지라는 핵심 목적과 직접적인 관련이 없다.

annotations.html: 해설: ⓔ 문장은 예술가가 창작 활동을 포기한다는 방향으로 전개되지만, 앞의 문단들은 불만족이 창작을 자극하는 원인이라고 설명하고 있어 흐름과 어긋난다. 전체 맥락에서 벗어난 내용이다.

annotations.html: ⑤
annotations.text: ⑤

annotations.html: 해설: 문장은 예술가가 창조적 행위를 통해 **객관적 현실 (objective reality)**이 아닌 **자신의 내면적 현실 (mental reality)**을 반영한다고 설명함. 여기서 "illusion (환상)"은 그 의미를 왜곡하며, '객관적 실재'라는 개념을 부정해 부적절함.

annotations.html: ③
annotations.text: ③

annotations.html:
-- 보기해석:
① 퇴역견이 훈련 후 정서적 지지가 필요한 이유
② 훈련된 개가 예상 밖으로 반려동물을 찾은 과정
③ 퇴역 구조견이 실종된 반려견을 구한 이야기
④ 사람과 동물의 유대가 시간이 지날수록 깊어지는 이유
⑤ 긴급 상황에서 협력의 중요성이 드러나는 방식
-- 해설: ③번은 퇴역 구조견 푸즈가 예상 밖 상황에서도 본능과 훈련을 바탕으로 반려견을 찾아낸 지문의 중심 이야기를 가장 잘 반영합니다. 다른 보기들은 일부 요소만 강조하거나 초점을 벗어났습니다.

annotations.html: ④
annotations.text: ④

annotations.html:
-- 보기해석:
① 화자와 퍼즈는 예전에 수색 구조팀으로 함께 일했다.
② 젊은 여성은 이웃에게서 퍼즈의 능력을 들었다.
③ 퍼즈는 이전까지 동물을 찾아본 적이 없었다.
④ 젊은 여성이 직접 덤불 뒤에서 오디를 발견했다.
⑤ 퍼즈는 눈에 잘 띄지 않는 오디를 결국 찾아냈다.
-- 해설: ④번은 글의 내용과 일치하지 않습니다. 덤불 뒤에서 오디를 발견한 것은 퍼즈이며, 직접 오디를 안고 들어온 사람은 화자입니다. 젊은 여성은 오디를 찾지 못하고 오히려 퍼즈와 화자에게 도움을 청했습니다. 따라서 ④번 문항이 정답입니다.

annotations.text: ⑤

annotations.html:
보기해석: 
① 푸즈가 이런 수색을 여러 번 했다는 사실에 나는 안심했 다. 
② 이전의 구조보다 이 일이 훨씬 쉬울 것이라는 확신이 들었다. 
③ 나는 푸즈에게 작은 반려동물을 찾는 훈련을 했던 기억이 났다. 
④ 그녀가 그 개를 빠르고 안전하게 찾을 거라는 의심이 없었다. 
⑤ 그녀가 다른 유형의 임무에 자신의 능력을 적용할 수 있을지 확신이 없었다.
해설: 빈칸 앞 문장은 푸즈가 사람을 찾도록 훈련되었음을 언급하며, 이어지는 문장은 반려동물 수색에 대한 걱정을 나타낸다. 이러한 흐름에 가장 잘 부합하는 선택지는 ⑤이며, 나머지 보기들은 본문의 상황과 감정과 어긋난다.

annotations.html: 해설: ⓒ 문장은 푸즈가 구조 임무에 나가기 직전 과거의 기억을 떠올리는 장면으로 문맥의 흐름과 다소 어긋나 있다. 전체적인 긴장감 있는 구조 상황과는 다르게 개인적인 회상으로 흐름이 분산된다.
